unittitle.value: Grand Army of the Republic, Department of New York, Harry Lee Post No. 21 records

extent.value: in one half manuscript box and one oversize box.

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The Grand Army of the Republic (GAR), a national fraternity of Union Army Civil War veterans, came to prominence in the late 19th century. This collection, spanning the period circa 1870 to 1935, contains records of the Brooklyn-based Harry Lee Post No. 21, a unit of the New York Department of the GAR. The records are comprised of member lists, meeting minutes, one photograph, and four bound volumes detailing the activities of the Post and the military backgrounds and personal histories of hundreds of Post members, with particular emphasis on their dates of death and burial locations.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Grand Army of the Republic, Department of New York, Harry Lee Post No. 21 records, 1977.078, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

The GAR reached its zenith in 1890 with a membership of over 400,000. At its annual state or national events known as "encampments," members from different posts would congregate to socialize, reconnect, and discuss organizational business. As the Civil War veterans began to pass away, membership naturally dwindled. The last national encampment was held in Indianapolis, IN, in 1949, followed by the close of the GAR's national office in 1956.

The collection also includes an 1892 indexed volume entitled 
                <emph render="italic">Personal War Sketches</emph>, a gift to the Post from Mary M. Doane in memory of her husband Charles R. Doane, one of the pillars of the Harry Lee community in the late 19th century. The volume devotes a page each to approximately 300 members, denoting the details of their births, military careers, and deaths. Due to its large size, the volume is housed separately from the rest of the collection in an oversize box.
